title: Expert Advice for Choosing the Right Skin Care Products for Your Skin Type

steps.title: What is your skin type?
steps.content: What is your skin type ? Your skin type is the default condition of your skin on any given day. [1] X Expert Source Nurse Shannan Product Reviewer Expert Interview. 14 April 2025. Many skin care products cater to specific skin types, so it helps to know which one you have before you start shopping around. [2] X Expert Source Paul Friedman, MD Board Certified Dermatologist, American Board of Dermatology Expert Interview. 8 April 2020. Here are the different categories: Normal: Skin that’s not especially dry, oily, or sensitive Oily: Skin with a shiny, greasy sheen Dry: Skin that itches, flakes, or feels rough to the touch Combination: A mixture of dry and oily skin Sensitive: Skin that tends to react to skincare products [3] X Trustworthy Source American Academy of Dermatology Professional organization made of over 20,000 certified dermatologists Go to source

steps.title: Do you want to target any skin concerns or issues in your skincare routine?
steps.content: Do you want to target any skin concerns or issues in your skincare routine? Maybe you’re battling a pesky round of acne, dealing with wrinkles, or coping with a rosacea flare-up. Whatever the case, look for skincare products that address these specific issues and concerns. [4] X Trustworthy Source Cleveland Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source You might: Get a product with salicylic acid to deal with acne Invest in retinol products [5] X Expert Source Nurse Shannan Product Reviewer Expert Interview. 14 April 2025. to minimize wrinkles [6] X Trustworthy Source Cleveland Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source Skip toner if you have rosacea [7] X Trustworthy Source American Academy of Dermatology Professional organization made of over 20,000 certified dermatologists Go to source

steps.title: Do you have any habits that directly affect your skin?
steps.content: Do you have any habits that directly affect your skin? Many different factors affect the way your skin looks and feels. This, in turn, affects the skincare products you’ll need to use. For instance, smoking or spending a lot of time in the sun means you'll want products that target collagen production and sun damage. [8] X Trustworthy Source Cleveland Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source

steps.title: Wash your face with a gentle cleanser twice per day.
steps.content: Wash your face with a gentle cleanser twice per day. Cleansers help clear away any oil, grime, and anything else that’s collected on your face. [9] X Trustworthy Source American Academy of Dermatology Professional organization made of over 20,000 certified dermatologists Go to source Dermatologists suggest squeezing a tiny bit of cleanser onto your fingertips and lightly massaging it into your skin. Then, rinse off any leftover suds with slightly warm water, and blot your skin with a gentle cloth until it’s completely dry. [10] X Research source Here are some skin-specific suggestions: Oily Skin: Gel cleanser with glycolic and salicylic acid Dry Skin: Cream cleanser with glycerin and petrolatum, lanolin, or ceramides Combination Skin: Gentle, balanced cleanser Sensitive Skin: Mild cleanser without dye, soap, or fragrance [11] X Research source Reader Poll: We asked 799 wikiHow readers how many products they use in their skincare routine, and 56% of them agreed that they just use water or maybe 1 product. [Take Poll] Until you know what works best for your skin, experiment with different products and routines, then adjust to match your skin’s needs.

steps.title: Nourish your freshly-cleaned skin with toner up to twice a day.
steps.content: Nourish your freshly-cleaned skin with toner up to twice a day. Toner helps nourish, lower redness, and eliminate dry sections on your skin. [12] X Research source All you have to do is squeeze a few drops of product onto a cotton ball and dab all over your damp skin after you’ve cleansed. Here are some skin type-specific suggestions: [13] X Research source Dry and Normal Skin: Toner with hyaluronic acid Oily Skin: Toner with alpha and beta hydroxy acids Sensitive Skin: Toner with hyaluronic acid that’s fragrance-free All Skin Types: Any toner that’s alcohol-free with antioxidants

steps.title: Target specific skin issues with serums.
steps.content: Target specific skin issues with serums . Are you noticing some fine lines starting to form, or does your skin just always seem to be inflamed? Whatever the case, serums are a great way to tackle specific issues. [14] X Research source Vitamin C serums are a really popular option that can help your skin look brighter and less red. They can even help boost collagen production, which helps your skin look a bit more youthful. [15] X Research source This could be helpful if you just quit smoking, since cigarettes hurt your skin’s collagen. [16] X Trustworthy Source Mayo Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source Although serums are an optional part of most skincare routines, some people find them helpful. [17] X Research source

steps.title: Exfoliate your face
steps.content: Exfoliate your face up to 2 times each week. [18] X Research source Exfoliating products help clear away dead skin cells, but they shouldn’t be used every day. [19] X Trustworthy Source American Academy of Dermatology Professional organization made of over 20,000 certified dermatologists Go to source Instead, experts advise using an exfoliator up to twice a week, between your cleanser and moisturizer. [20] X Research source Here are some skin type-specific suggestions: Oily Skin: Use a mechanical exfoliator or strong chemical exfoliator Dry Skin: Use a gentle chemical exfoliator Sensitive Skin: Use a gentle chemical exfoliator Mechanical exfoliators require physical motion to exfoliate your skin, like using a bristled brush or exfoliating scrub. Chemical exfoliators are products made with exfoliating ingredients and aren’t as rough on your skin. [21] X Trustworthy Source American Academy of Dermatology Professional organization made of over 20,000 certified dermatologists Go to source

steps.title: Hydrate your skin every day with lotion or moisturizer while it’s damp.
steps.content: Hydrate your skin every day with lotion or moisturizer while it’s damp. Moisturizers help lock moisture into your face, creating a vibrant glow. [22] X Trustworthy Source American Academy of Dermatology Professional organization made of over 20,000 certified dermatologists Go to source Dermatologists suggest applying this product throughout the year, so your skin can always stay hydrated. [23] X Research source Here are some specific product suggestions, depending on your skin type: Oily Skin: Water-based, oil-free moisturizer Dry Skin: Oil-based moisturizer Combination Skin: Medium-weight lotion Sensitive Skin: Hypoallergenic and fragrance-free moisturizer [24] X Trustworthy Source Mayo Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source

steps.title: Apply 30 SPF sunscreen every day to protect your skin.
steps.content: Apply 30 SPF sunscreen every day to protect your skin. Daily sun exposure can damage your skin over time, so it’s important to stay protected. [25] X Trustworthy Source American Academy of Dermatology Professional organization made of over 20,000 certified dermatologists Go to source Rub sunscreen on any exposed parts of your skin about 15 minutes before you plan on heading out the door—this way, the product has enough time to soak into your skin. [26] X Trustworthy Source American Academy of Dermatology Professional organization made of over 20,000 certified dermatologists Go to source A cherry tomato-sized squirt of sunscreen should be enough to protect your face. [27] X Research source Try to apply a new layer of sunscreen every 2 hours if you spend a lot of time out in the sun. [28] X Trustworthy Source American Academy of Dermatology Professional organization made of over 20,000 certified dermatologists Go to source Remember: you should always wear sunscreen when you head outside, even if you have a tan complexion or dark skin tone. [29] X Trustworthy Source Cleveland Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source

steps.title: Treat wrinkles and blemishes with alpha-hydroxy acids (AHAs).
steps.content: Treat wrinkles and blemishes with alpha-hydroxy acids (AHAs). Also known as tartaric, glycolic, lactic, and citric acids, AHAs help reduce age spots, wrinkles, fine lines, and pigmentation issues. You can find them in a variety of over-the-counter creams and lotions. [30] X Trustworthy Source Cleveland Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source Skincare experts suggest picking out products with a low AHA concentration so you don’t bother your skin. Anywhere between 10 and 15% should be good!

steps.title: Clear away dead skin with beta-hydroxy acids.
steps.content: Clear away dead skin with beta-hydroxy acids. Also known as salicylic acid, this ingredient helps boost the tone and texture of skin damaged by the sun. It’s also a common ingredient in acne treatments. You can find it in plenty of over-the-counter skincare productions, as well as in prescription treatments. [31] X Trustworthy Source Cleveland Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source Products with beta-hydroxy acids may be a little easier on your skin than products with AHAs.

steps.title: Hydrate and firm your skin with hyaluronic acid.
steps.content: Hydrate and firm your skin with hyaluronic acid. Hyaluronic acid is found naturally in your joints and skin, but your body’s levels of it decrease when you get older. Thankfully, there’s plenty of hyaluronic acid in topical, over-the-counter products, which hydrate your skin and tackle your wrinkles head-on. [32] X Trustworthy Source Cleveland Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source

steps.title: Improve your skin’s appearance with retinol.
steps.content: Improve your skin’s appearance with retinol. This ingredient reduces fine lines, decreases wrinkles, and gives your skin texture a boost. You can find it in a variety of creams and serums at your local drugstore. [33] X Trustworthy Source Cleveland Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source

steps.title: Get younger-looking skin with L-ascorbic acid.
steps.content: Get younger-looking skin with L-ascorbic acid. Also known as vitamin C, L-ascorbic acid helps boost your skin’s collagen production, which helps reduce wrinkles, lines, and other blemishes. Skincare products with L-ascorbic acid may irritate your skin at first, but your skin should adjust over time. [34] X Trustworthy Source Cleveland Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source You can find L-ascorbic acid in plenty of over-the-counter skincare products.

steps.title: Lighten your skin with hydroquinone.
steps.content: Lighten your skin with hydroquinone. This ingredient directly impacts your melanin production and can treat different types of hyperpigmentation, like freckles, acne scars, and age spots. [35] X Research source You can easily find hydroquinone creams at your local pharmacy, but you’ll need a prescription to get a more potent formula. [36] X Trustworthy Source Cleveland Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source Keep in mind that the medical community has a divided opinion about hydroquinone, and some health professionals link it with serious health issues. [37] X Research source

steps.title: Blacklist products that are made with potentially dangerous ingredients.
steps.content: Blacklist products that are made with potentially dangerous ingredients. Unfortunately, not all skincare products and ingredients are created equally. Some skincare ingredients are actually harmful to your body, and can potentially lead to serious side effects. Here are a few ingredients to watch out for: [38] X Research source Fragrance Homosalate Nanomaterials Octinoxate Parabens For a full list of concerning ingredients, check out this list: https://www.safecosmetics.org/get-the-facts/chem-of-concern/
